transcript.title: United States Postal Service v. Gregory

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We'll hear argument now in Number oh oh seven fifty-eight, United States Postal Service versus Maria A Gregory.
Mr. Garre.
[Inaudible]
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

For decades Federal employers and the Merit Systems Protection Board have engaged in the common sense practice of considering an employee's prior disciplinary record in deciding what punishment is appropriate for subsequent misconduct.

The settled practice has long been to do so, even when a prior disciplinary action is subject to a pending labor grievance, although in that context, the board permits the employee to collaterally attack the prior actions in proceedings before it.
In this case, the Federal circuit...
overtur-
If there...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: is a collateral attack, the employee says, look, I filed a grievance and it's pending, what then is the burden of proof by the Government employer?
The Government employer bears the burden of proving the action by a preponderance of the evidence.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But what what is it with regard to the prior offenses, if you will, that have for which grievance procedures have been filed? How is that then addressed?

Under the loun- longstanding framework, which is established by the board's Bolling decision, the employer has to prove the fact of the prior action, and he has to, and the employer has to im- prove that it was preceded by certain procedural protections, first, that the employee received advance notice of the action, second, that the employee had an opportunity to respond to the charges before the supervisor, as well as by a higher authority within the agency, and third, that there was a record...
proceeding...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: mean somebody higher up the ladder in the employing agency?
It does, a- and that's and th- that's the same type of challenge that is framed in the early stages of the grievance process.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, what if the final action, the decision to terminate the services of the employee what if it had been based on the commission of some prior failure as an employee and the grievance procedure had proceeded and it had been determined that it was invalid?
In that circumstance, the board has held that it would be inappropriate to rely on that action to defend the subsequent action.
disciplinary actions...
What happens...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: fact, here three preceding incidents, as I recall, and a grievance was filed on all of them.
That's correct.
disciplinary action.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Justice O'Connor's example? And let me add one thing, that the prior disciplinary actions are being grieved.
Well, first of all, there's grievances can be pressed before, during, and after appeals before the Merit Systems Protection Board.
the appeal...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the answer to my question?
It...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: question was do you, should I repeat it or you have it?
i-, My understanding is that in, even when a grievance is proceeding, the board would would proceed with the processing of its...
appeal.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: question is take the present situation.
I'm sorry.
basis for infal-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: to my hypothetical, it can't happen.
The board can't go to an arbitrator and tell him...
to stop.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: what about the employer? Can the postal department s- d- say , well, you know, this this sh- sh- she's not an employee here anyway, we're, you don't need to continue this? Or is it y- you you leave me with the impression, rightly or wrongly, that this this i- the that this is just at the option of the union.
It's...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: proceed if it wants or doesn't have to proceed.
That's a matter covered by the collective bargaining agree- arrangement.
that employers can't...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: but what we're trying to establish and I think you would have to concede that there are some instances in which once the employee is terminated, the grievance proceedings as to other matters must stop.
That can happen and it happens at,
because of...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: just because it's the option of the union other than what the union agreed to in the collective bargaining agreement.
The arrangement is the the grievances are withdrawn by the union or they're ri- withdrawn under the arrangement that's been worked out under the...
collective bargaining agreement.
collective...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: bargaining agreement is silent.
That that would be a decision left to the arbitrator under the framework of the negotiated grievance.
can happen. And...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: e- if it's c- covered by the collective bargaining agreement, there's no choice in the matter, the grievance is stopped.
Now, this may not be...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: fatal to your case, but if this happens, I think we should confront it.
And Justice Breyer...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: this would happen.
That's right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And the union could say, you know, I think you deserved it and and we're not going to proceed any further.
That's correct.
leaves to the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: is not an inju- if if that if that's what it is, is not an injustice peculiar to this arrangements.
That's right.
Mr. Garre?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: In civil litigation generally, when there when there's a proceeding that's dependent on a prior proceeding that's on appeal, the standard operating procedure is for the second proceeding to be held at abeyance pending the appeal of the first.
It's it's very problematic.
estoppel effect. But...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: doesn't prevent it, but it is the standard proceeding to hold the second one in abeyance.
But...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So that you don't have the the anomaly of giving effect to a judgment that has been overturned.
Th- There are several problems with the abeyance rule adopted by the Federal circuit, which is essentially the narrow rule which is hypothesized by respondent.
Why if i-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: why, if the agency action goes into effect immediately? What what I'm presenting to you is the the thing goes through the agency.

Well, first of all, although the employee is paced in, placed in a non-duty, non-pay status when she's removed by the agency, she continues to fill a permanent slot on the agency's rolls, and if the abeyance rule is going to require agencies to keep the employee in that position for months, if not years, on end, that's problematic from the employer's perspective.
the abeyance...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: i- i- would you explain that if to me? Two, why would the why if the firing is is okay, at least until it's overturned, why couldn't the the agency fill the vacancy?

The the employee is placed under the practice followed by the Postal Service and I believe other employers as well, the employee occupies the full-time slot, and until her removal is affirmed by the board, she continues to fill that slot.
on end. It also...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May may I just ask you to get into this problem of months and years? The months and years problem I I understand is is simply a function of of what you claim to be the slow pace of arbitration.
I I think they have tried, but the fact is that in the Postal Service, there's currently a hundred and twenty-six thousand grievances pending in that process, backlogged.
And this is the situation that...
Well, this is the situation that exists, and the board isn't required to hold its appeals in abeyance while that...
procedure is played out.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: my my poin- I guess my point is that you say this is the situation that exists.
Well, first of all, the inherent informality of the grievance and arbitration process is always going to invite delay.
Well, litigation...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: invites delay.
Well, that hasn't happened, and I don't think it's unique to the Postal Service ar- arbitration context.
Mr. Garre, d-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: d- do you think that for purposes of either collateral estoppel or for purposes of whether a criminal court can use a prior conviction in deciding the sentence d- do you think it it's accurate to analogize the grievance procedure as a prior case pending on appeal? Or would you rather characterize it as a collateral attack...
I think it's...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: final action by the employer?
I I think it's the latter.
proceeding to...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: and what happens to collateral attacks when you have a final criminal conviction and there is a collateral attack on that criminal conviction, although the conviction itself is final? When a sentencing court has that conviction before it, does it not use that conviction.
Absolutely.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And if the collateral attack is later successful, what is what is the remedy for the...
person who's been convicted?
they can bring it to the attention of the...
court and ask for relief.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: to reopen the proceeding.
That's correct.
And that and that...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: do here? We have a case here where, as I understand it, there were three prior complaints by the employer that resulted in some form of disciplinary action.
Well, we think that this Court should decide the question presented, reverse the decision below, and remand for further proceedings,
allow the Federal circuit...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: to the other two grievances...
The other two...
grievances were withdrawn by the union when the board affirmed the the removal.
This the Federal circuit...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: remand necessary? What i- i- if we agree with with you on the merits, what what remains to be decided by the Federal circuit?
The the issue that that remains open is the question of what effect the grievance that has been set aside should have on the board's decision affirming the removal.
address...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You say if we reverse on the question presented, we should leave it to the Federal circuit to decide whether to direct reopening of the proceedings or to affirm the MSPB?
We we th- we th- that's what we would ask this Court to do.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: There's a disagreement between you and the respondent, is there not, about whether the m- b- the agency, the Postal Service, is bound or whether it's only the MSPB.
Well, we we think that the fairest reading of the court of appeals decision, as it applies both to Federal employers and the Merit Systems Protection Board, the holding of the court is unqualified.
proceedings.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Their their point on that particularly is what were you is, all right the the particular point I think on that is that the the Federal circuit really just said the M the MSPB.
Well, first of all, we don't we don't think that's the fairest interpretation of the court of appeals decision.
That's one of the problems...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: d- does the Government acknowledge that the MSPB can determine that it is arbitrary, capricious, or an abuse of discretion for the agency to decline to reopen a proceeding after a grievance has gone forward and has found one of the convictions on which the dismissal is based to have been invalid?
The the the board's regulations permit the board to reopen any case at any time to reconsider it in light of a grievance which may have proved successful.
to request...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: regulations permit that?
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: board's right? Doesn't the board have to find that the agency action, in refusing to reopen, is arbitrary, capricious, or an abuse of discretion? I mean, the board can say when it will reopen it's own cases, but but the board can't tell the agency when the agency must reopen its cases, can it, unless the failure to reopen is arbitrary or capricious?
No.
board's reopening rule.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: talking about ultimate success in the grievance and then then the employee comes back to the agency and says, look, you you goofed.
Well, certainly in that...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: board find that to be an abuse of discretion?
That's the the typical practice is that the employee will go to the board and say, reopen my appeal because this grievance has proved successful.
So, typically...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: PB rule, that you if if while the MSPB thing is still going on, one of the grievances e- the MSPB, if the person hasn't been fired, will reconsider.
The the employee may do that, and the board may do that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But it's discretionary, isn't it? That the board doesn't have to reopen if it doesn't want to.
It is discretionary, and that's really no different than any other reopening procedure which would exist to to enable a court or other body to reconsider something in light of subsequent evidence.
that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: on the proposition that they are not final in in in the sense that that that a a judicial determination is final.
We think that they are final.
I don't want to consume your...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: rebuttal time, but there's one question that that that that still hasn't been answered for me.

We think that the board can take those into account under the Bolling framework, which allows the board to consider the prior disciplinary actions under a procedural perfr- framework which looks to the procedural protections provided in those proceedings and then considers whether those actions...
What would your...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: position be before the Postal Service as to the union's request to reopen those?
To reopen the?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Those to or to continue those un- una- those pretermitted grievance proceedings.
Those arbitrations could go forward.
that per-

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: no objection to those going forward?
The arbi- the...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I thought the union was obje-
wanting...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: to go forward, the and the Postal Service didn't.

Under the memorandum that's in place, if the respondent's removal were affirmed by the board, then under the memorandum in place, the union's practice is to withdraw those agreements under the collective bargaining arrangement.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Garre, apropos of the remand, you mentioned that the respondent had not brought to the board's attention the fact that the arbitrator had ordered the first disciplinary action vacated.
of the board?
bring that to the attention of the board.
Thank you, Mr. Garre.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Brands, we'll hear from you.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
The MSPB --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: talking now about review before the MSPB, not before the Federal circuit.
Is that correct?

The MSPB has held that whenever the agency comes before the MSPB and relies on aggravating facts, not necessarily the particular charge before the MSPB, but other things, for example, the employee is simply not very good or or something like that, that has to be proven as well by by a preponderance de novo in the MSPB.
I do not...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: even if a grievance is not pending, the board would have to review the prior disciplinary action to be sure that that was supported by a preponderance of the evidence? Surely it surely it doesn't mean that.
Well, Justice Scalia, I think that the burden of proof is always the same.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah, but the burden of proof is this employee has been convicted of prior disciplinary violations in the past.
And...
QED, proven.
Certainly when...
But you're you're...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: saying that's not enough.
No, Justice Scalia, we're not saying that.
But that is not...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: same presumption still valid even though the the action is being grieved?
Well, two things...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: not as though it were unilateral employer action without a hearing and procedural guarantees.
That is certainly...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: judgment is final until un- un- and what you're grieving is employer action, and and that action is final until a grievance overturns it.

Justice Scalia, I think that the analogy that the Government would like to draw is to an agency action that is subject to section seven oh six review under the APA, but that is not the right analogy, we respectfully submit.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, what we're reviewing here, Mr. Brands, is not the Merit Systems Protection Board's action, but the action the Federal circuit.
Right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: As I understand it, the Federal circuit here said this was not in accordance with law.

Well, that is true, and perhaps the brevity of the a- of the discussion by the court of appeals can be explained on the ground of of the fact that the Government did not respond to any of respondent's arguments in the court of appeals.
proof.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: but you you you say it's u- not in accordance with law, and then in the same sentence, you say it arbitrarily disregards the burden of proof.
And that's...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: a- and which I don't think the Federal circuit did.
That is correct, but nevertheless, its judgment, we think, is is right on the money.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Now, the the that's that's s- standard you say governs the Merit Systems Protection Board?
That is correct.
so on and so...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the basis for the Federal circuit's decision here.
We think it actually was, Your Honor, because...
under...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Where d- where do you find that?
[Inaudible]
the petition appendix seven A where the court of appeals said that its rule is necessary because the foundation of the board of the MSPB's Douglas analysis would otherwise be compromised.
is...
And again, we would we would suggest that the del- telegraphic nature of that may may also be blamed on the Government's conduct of...
the litigation in the court of appeals.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: blamed on the Government?
Well, let let me just explain real quick what we think that the court of appeals meant by that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I thought you already conceded in in response to an earlier question of mine that y- that the that the board does not have to establish by a preponderance of the evidence the accuracy of any prior disciplinary conviction.
I don't think I said that, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Oh, I thought you did.
If you -- then why isn't it true? Suppose there had...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: been no grievance.
Well, the the statutory burden, of course, always applies.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, your answer is yes.
No, it's not necessarily yes.
Well.
I would distinguish between three factual scenarios.
proving...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: to he or she.
No, that's actually not entirely true.
the right to do that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: still that isn't this case.
[Inaudible]

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, because this in this case we have a grievance that was not fully determined.
That's pre- that's precisely correct,
Your Honor. We have in this particular case...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: trouble with the proposition you just stated, but this case is with an with an unadjudicated grievance or or grievance with, that had not been fully determined.
Precisely.
Mr. Brands,

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: as I understand it, the board, MSPB, applies its so-called Bolling rule.
to meet...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: the statute?
We th- we don't think it is enough in a situation like this situation where the prior is being grieved, and here's...
why.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: challenge the Bolling rule? Is that something we've been asked to review here?
Well, the Bolling rule is squarely before the Court.
wrong...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: assert that he- if if the board applies its Bolling standard, that is not enough to s- satisfy the statutory burden of proof?
We think it is enough in a situation where the prior has become final on its own steam.
the burden.

That is correct, although that burden will be very easy to discharge in a case where a prior has already become final or, for that matter, where a prinor- prior was never attacked.

text_blocks.text: Mr. Garre, you have two minutes remaining.
The Federal circuit ruling in this case is not based in any way on the burden of proof applied in board proceedings.
